Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Thank you for your detailed reply.

I am very impressed with SharpNEAT. Thanks for sharing it.

I do not understand how I am losing the most fit. My evaluation routine is
completely consistent -- I have 500 test cases with expected results 0 or 1
and my fitness per individual is 1 - (abs(expectedValue - outputValue)) so
the best possible fitness is 500.

I do not expect you to debug this but in case it does catch your interest I
have included the relevant files. Here is the section for the app.config:

<experiment>
	<title>Genotype to Phenotype</title>
	<description>Predict an outcome given attribute values. Data is a tab
delimited
file with first line defining columns. The last column is the expected
output (0 or 1).
All other columns are attributes with their values. For example, the
attributes might be
SNP locations and the values are either 1, 2, or 3 meaning homozygous
allele1,
heterozygous allele1 and allele2, and homozygous allele2 respectively.
Datafile url is relative to the location of the SharpNeat.exe
file.</description>
	<assemblyUrl>SharpNeatExperiments.dll</assemblyUrl>
	<typeName>SharpNeatLib.Experiments.GenotypeToPhenotypeExperiment</typeName>
	<experimentParameters>
		<dataFileRelativePath>GenotypeToPhenotypeExperiment/Atrial
fibrillation.txt
		</dataFileRelativePath>
	</experimentParameters>
</experiment>

The attachments are two zipped folders: one is the src files which belongs
in src/Experiments/SharpNEATExperiments and the other is the dataFile which
should be placed in the same  folder as the SharpNEAT.exe


I will let you know if I figure out how the most fit species is being lost.

Thanks,

Peter

-----Original Message-----
From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Thursday, July 13, 2006 6:01 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Loss of most fit species in SharpNEAT?


petervermont wrote:

>I have noticed that my best fitness sometimes declines.
>
>While I can sort of understand this if I have enabled 'pruning', it
>also occurs even when I disable pruning.
>
>I suspected that in long runs, my most fit individual was stagnant and
>stopped improving its fitness and therefore was being killed when
>'Species Dropoff Age' was exceeded. To counteract this, I set the
>Species Dropoff age to an absurdly large number to effectively disable
>it but the most fit individual still was eventually killed and my best
>fitness declined.
>
>Since I have the very nice feature 'Save Genome On Improvement'
>enabled I guess I don't mind terribly since clearing out species which
>have stopped improving makes way for other explorations.
>
>Have other people noticed this? Do you consider a bug or a feature?
>How could I avoid this if I chose to?
>
>

Ok two points to start with:

1) SharpNEAT will always preserve the species with the best genome, even
if it has reached the drop-off age.
2) Pruning isn't really a factor, if pruning away structure results in
all of the offspring being less fit then the elite genomes will survive
through to the next generation. This combined with point (1) means that
elite genomes can survive indefinitely if necessary and therefore you
should not see the best fitness fall.

There is however one scenario I know of that can result in the best
fitness falling, and that is if an inconsistent evaluation scheme is
being used. In fact I'm running just such an experiment right now - I
have some share/stock trading data and I evaluate genomes (each
representing a trading strategy) over the data, this normally means that
a genome will always give exactly the same fitness score. However, in
order to improve robustness of the evolved genomes I introduce some
noise into the trading data, this means that a given genome's fitness
can actually change from generation to generation. So typically the best
genome will be re-evaulated over and over again and may give slightly
different results each time. Now if that varation is large enough then
another genome (or species) may temporarily become the best, causing the
previous champ to be lost - or in the case of a species the species' age
may now be tested against the drop-off threshold causing the whole
species to be culled.

You can alleviate this problem by maintaining an average score for each
genome as they are re-evaluated. I currently do this and although it
doesn;t rpevent the best fitness from falling it does help. You can
further allieviate the problem by configuring sharpneat to preserve a
large proportion of each species on each generation, this is the
'elitism proportion' setting on the second tab page.

These aren't 100% solutions but I find them acceptible for my own
experiments right now. In fact I don't even adjust the elitism
proportion, but maybe you want to try it.

If you think about the natural world then the problem is lesser because
populations sizes are (normally) so much larger, so good combinations of
genomes are going to be surving out there somewhere in some
sub-population. Also disabling genes rather than deleting them might
also help, that way any good combinations are more likely to re-emerge
in the future. I think Ken's NEAT disabled genes but I took the very
simple approach of deleting them.

I hope some of that helps,

Colin.
